awd_titl_txt: Fundamental Study of Friction with Hierarchically Ruga-controlled Surfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports fundamental research on the mechanics of friction applicable to modern nanotechnology as well as geotechnical science and engineering. Since the time of Leonardo da Vinci, friction - sliding resistance between two objects - has been one of the most challenging subjects still incomplete in understanding but crucial in advancement of modern science and technology. For example, it is critical in controlling sliding mechanisms in nano-manipulators as well as in measuring and predicting forces building up at tectonic fault lines. Here, the principal investigator plans to develop an innovative mechanics framework - renormalization of friction, i.e. successive evaluation of larger length scale friction with smaller length scale friction behavior, and verify it with controlled experiments. The fundamental studies of this project will establish a systematic framework for regulating nanoscale friction to control macroscopic friction. The multi-scale framework of friction will be essential for developing not only nano-mechanical device technology but also friction-control technology in robotics and bio-medical device engineering, as well as for solving scientific problems in geology. It will also advance computational modeling and design capabilities for manufacturing processes sensitive to friction control, widely encountered in production industries. In addition, under this project, the principal investigator will develop an outreach program at Brown, to educate underrepresented students through summer internship programs, and to develop new course material.

Over the past two and half decades, research on multi-scale frictional processes has been very active to uncover the molecular origin of these processes and to bridge understanding of the phenomena at different length scales. Recently the principal investigator's group revealed that renormalization softening/strengthening of friction develops depending on the reduction of molecular adhesive friction stress, scale-dependent flattening of asperities or stiffening of the surface. This unique scheme of friction renormalization is very powerful in investigating multi-scale friction processes of rough surfaces. With this award, the principal investigator will study (i) renormalization strengthening in rough-surface friction; (ii) Ruga (surface corrugation) control of hierarchical roughness to study renormalization of friction; (iii) evolution of roughness spectra and friction due to asperity plasticity and wear.

Outcomes Report of NSF: Award 1563591. 03/01/2016 – 02/28/2019

Fundamental Study of Friction with Hierarchically Ruga-controlled Surfaces

PI: Kyung-Suk Kim.

In this project, an innovative interface roughness layer(IRL) model is developed and used to bridge understandings in scale-dependent processes of rough-surface friction byrenormalizing the scale-dependent friction parameters.The atomic-scale friction parameters are evaluated by the density functional theory (DFT), and renormalized for the upper-scale friction processes. The IRL renormalization approach opens a pathway towards the ‘mechanism-based micromechanics’ of friction beyond the phenomenological friction laws for various spectra of the frictional-surface roughness. The renormalization group flow from the molecular friction to the Amontons-type friction reveals renormalization softening/strengthening mechanisms of friction. The new approach is expected to trigger diverse development of computational as well as experimental tools to analyze and control friction at broad scales from those of nano-manipulators to tectonic plates. The project has resulted in 4 major journal publications and 8 conference articles. The results have been presented at national and international conferences and institutional seminars, including 

*K.-S. Kim, "Micromechanics of Adhesion at Broad Scales: From Molecular to Continuum Adhesion," Plenary Lecture, The Adhesion Society 40th Annual Meeting, St. Petersburg, Florida, February, 2017.

* K.-S. Kim, "Hidden, forbidden and inherited spectrum of roughness caused by multilayer deformation instabilities near a free surface," CECAM Workshop: Emergence of surface and interface structure from friction, fracture and deformation, Invited Lecture, Lausanne, Switzerland, July, 2018.

*K.-S. Kim, “Scale Effects in Friction at Broad Scales: Roughness Scaling Experiment,” NSF Workshop, Geophysics Symposium, UCSD, San Diego, CA, June, 2019.

Intellectual Merit: The fundamental studies of friction renormalization for hierarchically ruga-controlled surfacesprovide a new paradigm of controlling friction not only at a small- but also at a very large-length scale. These studieshave established a systematic framework for regulating nanoscale friction and controlling macroscopic friction. In addition, the renormalization scheme has provided many important multi-scale modeling and experimental capabilities in high-performance computing and multi-scale testing of scale-dependent frictional processes. 

BroaderImpacts: The project resultsmake broad impactson other branches of science and technology,including nanotribology, friction-control in robotics and bio-medical device engineering, and modeling technology for solving scientific problems in geology. This projectwill also advance computational modeling and design capabilities for manufacturing processes sensitive to friction control, widely encountered in production industries. Under this project, 4 graduate students, 2 REU students from Ecole Polytech, Paris, and 3 post docs were trained for periods of  3 to 12 months. Two undergraduate, one MS,and one PhD theses were written by the students.
